body.p: In the coastal United States, there is an established correlation between ice cream sales and shark attacks. Which of the following might we conclude from this data?

input.choice: Eating ice cream may increase the likelihood of a shark attack.
Increases in shark attacks may increase ice cream sales.
This is an anomaly and there is no relationship between shark attacks and ice cream sales.
There may be a third variable that creates a link between ice cream sales and shark attacks.

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it may be possible that there is a mechanism by which sharks might be attracted to ice cream, it is not the likely choice. Since shark attacks tend to happen when people swim, which is in warm weather, and ice cream sales also tend to increase during warm weather, there is a likely lurking variable here that confounds the results.

body.p: Suppose a study finds a positive correlation between the number of TV sets in the home of high school seniors and their admission rate into college. Which of the following might we conclude from this data?

input.choice: The increase in home TV sets improves the likelihood of college admission.
Better students tend to have a TV set available.
There may be a third variable that creates a link between the number of TVs in the home and college admission rate.
This is an anomaly and there is no relationship between TVs in the home and college admission rate.

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it may be possible that there is a mechanism by which more TVs in the home may increase chances of college admission, it is not the likely choice. Since the number of TVs in the home tend to be correlated with the income and education of the parents and students from wealthier homes with more educated parents tend to have a better admission rate into college there is a likely lurking variable here that confounds the results.

Incorrect. It seems unlikely that better students tend to be the ones watching the most TV.
